content.description: Start about 100 feet to the right of the Eleventh Wave, on the opposite side of the trail.Climb a hidden, right facing corner to the top.
content.location: Start about 100 feet to the right of the Eleventh Wave, on the opposite side of the trail.

climbs.name: The Eleventh Wave
climbs.fa: FA (A1): Todd Swain 08-1980 FFA (free): perhaps John Strand 1985

content.description: Start at the thin, overhanging crack that is just right of Fissure Hop.This was originally aid climbed (A1), then freed at least as early as 1985.The name comes from the Ninth Wave at Whitehorse - this is a little steeper.
content.location: Start at the thin, overhanging crack that is just right of Fissure Hop.

content.description: Start 70 feet right of Coren Crack and above the trail at a left leaning ramp capped by a ceiling.P1: Layback up the ramp then hand traverse right under the ceiling and mantle onto a ledge (crux).P2: Climb an easy crack to the top (40 feet).This route was first attempted with Rich Couchon in 08-1979. Hexes were used to protect the traverse but neither Swain nor Couchon could do the mantle. Swain returned a year later and rope soloed the route (he had obviously improved as a climber!).
content.location: Start 70 feet right of Coren Crack and above the trail at a left leaning ramp capped by a ceiling.

content.description: Obvious overhanging crack system to the right of Rich's Roof. It is above the trail to the summit.
content.location: Start to the right of Rich's Roof at an overhanging crack.

climbs.name: Coren Crack
climbs.fa: Rich Couchon, Pete & Steve Coren, Todd Swain 08-1979

content.description:
Start at the left end of the cliff below the summit and above the trail. 

  Climb some flakes to reach an obvious hand crack that leads to a ledge. Climb flakes and an arÃªte to the top.
content.location: Start at the left end of the cliff below the summit and above the trail.

content.description: This is the North Summit of Sugarloaf with a few smaller (20 - 40 ft high) , almost "boulder problem" routes (by the stds of the 21st Century's "Highballers). That being said, a rope is recommended since the bases are pretty "gnarly" by bouldering standards!
